> Fr=
om: Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.=
com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Mon, 10 Nov 2008 08:13:17 -0000
> To: "=
neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: [neat] Re: Crossove=
r doing anything in HyperNEAT and PNEAT?
> 
> The question about crossover =
in NEAT is interesting.  Although it does
> not provide a huge boost in per=
formance, it is still a significant
> advance compared to what came before =
in neuroevolution, which is why
> it is still a payoff.  The competing conv=
entions problem (also called
> the "topology matching problem") was a huge =
issue in neuroevolution
> before NEAT, and because of it some researchers w=
ere questioning
> whether there was any hope for crossover at all in such s=
ystems.  It
> could be shown in prior systems without historical marking th=
at
> crossover actually hurts the evolution of neural networks, making its
=
> prospects dim.  Angeline and Pollack even introduced a neuroevolution
> m=
ethod called GNARL (before NEAT) that didn't even have crossover as
> an op=
erator because of the concern.  In this context, NEAT made
> crossover safe=
 for neuroevolution and removed its stigma in such
> systems.  That is, it =
switched it from a liability to an advantage
> that boosts performance a bi=
t in NEAT.  So it's an advance in that sense.
> 
> However, while the "bit"=
 of performance gain (vs. having no crossover)
> *is* likely statistically =
significant, it is not huge.  The real
> benefit of historical markings
> i=
s that it enables speciation, which does have a dramatic effect
> because o=
f protecting innovation to support complexification.
> Crossover is more li=
ke icing on the cake.  However, I think many
> people identify NEAT with cr=
ossover because it is such a clear
> demonstration of the benefit of histor=
ical markings.  In that sense,
> it is perhaps conceptually more significan=
t than it is functionally.
> Still, I would recommend keeping it if you can=
, since it does appear
> to be better to have it than not, albeit not enorm=
ously.
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> w=
rote:
>> 
>> Thanks Ken. I was guessing the same thing based on (1). I can'=
t
> think of any
>> good reason at the moment why crossover would help/hurt=
 HyperNEAT
> more than
>> P-NEAT. 
>> 
>> (2) surprises me, however. Isn't =
one of the hallmarks of NEAT the
>> intelligent crossover via historical ma=
rkings? I guess I just
> assumed that
>> had been shown to provide a huge p=
ayoff. If crossover doesn't help
> that much
>> in NEAT, how much does *int=
elligent* (vs. na=EFve) crossover help?
>> 
>> 
>> 
>> 
>> 
>> Cheers,
>> J=
eff Clune
>> 
>> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
>> 
>> jc=
lune@...
>> 
>> 
>>

wn crossover in NEAT to improve performance marginally but not

ally.

>>>>> Hey Jeff,
>>>>> 
>>>>> Yeah, it =
looks like you hit the nail on the head.  Right now, it
>>>>> either comple=
tely chooses one parent or the other, but putting that
>>>>> code inside of=
 the loop will make it treat each gene individually
>>>>> (this will perfor=
m real crossover).
>>>>> 
>>>>> I'm going to put in the change and see how =
it changes my
> experiments.
>>>>>  Assuming it doesn't break anything, I'l=
l roll this into the next
>>>>> version.  If it affects the results in a ne=
gative way, I'll make a
>>>>> parameter for it so you can choose to use cro=
ssover or not.
>>>>> 
>>>>> Thanks for the find!
>>>>>

>>>>> --- In=
 neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> Well yes=
 this is exactly what it has to be. Note that
>>> randomChoice has
>>>>>>> =
to be random every time you refer to it. If it is not random (i.e.
>>>>>>> =
outside the big loop) then you choose links from either parent.
>>> But if
=
>>>>>>> it is inside the loop, then you choose a gene randomly from either
=
>>>>>>> parent. Check this out and you will have a clearer picture if
>>> t=
here is
>>>>>>> a bug or not.
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Thanks Petar. I am confident t=
hat HyperNEAT 2.5 chooses the parent
>>>>> outside
>>>>>> the loop, and thu=
s grabs all links from either parent1 or parent2.
>>>>> What I am
>>>>>> tr=
ying to find out is whether this is by design, or if it is a bug.
>>>>>> 
>=
>>>>> Do you (or anyone else) happen to know how it works in other NEAT
>>>=
>> packages,
>>>>>> in particular Ken's original NEAT code? My guess is tha=
t we are
>>>>> supposed to
>>>>>> be grabbing some links from parent1 and s=
ome other links from
>>> parent2,
>>>>>> instead of one or the other. I can=
 go check those packages, of
>>>>> course, but I
>>>>>> won't be able to do=
 that for a little while and was wondering
> if any
>>>>> of you
>>>>>> kne=
w off the top of your heads.
>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> But the cloning issue is a dee=
per one. In this case you must
> ensure
>>>>>>> that individuals should not=
 mate with themselves or such ones that
>>>>>>> have zero compatibility dis=
tance. Or at least try a few hundred
>>> times
>>>>>>> to find a different =
mate :) Hey, I say this to all users.
> Don't use
>>>>>>> rand(), fuck that=
, use the Mersenne Twister instead. I noticed
>>> that in
>>>>>>> enhances =
performance!
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Fair enough, but right now I am more focused on=
 the more
>>> immediate issue
>>>>>> above. Thanks for the suggestions, tho=
ugh. I will delve into them
>>> when I
>>>>>> resolve the other issue.
>>>>=
>> 
>>>>>> Thanks. Jeff.
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> Peter
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> --- In nea=
t@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Hi Petar-=

>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Thanks for the reply. I do not have a (non-HyperNEAT) N=
EAT
> package
>>>>>>> around.
>>>>>>>> Can you let me know if your NEAT imp=
lementation is different than
>>>>>>> what I
>>>>>>>> report below?
>>>>>>>=
> 
>>>>>>>> I am using Jason's HyperNEAT 2.5 package available here:
>>>>>>=
>> 
>>>>>>>> http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/software.html
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> If yo=
u download the package, the key file is:
>>>>>>>> HyperNEAT/NEAT/src/NEAT_G=
eneticIndividual.cpp
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> I am attaching it, but I don't know=
 how that works with the yahoo
>>>>>>> group.
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Crossover =
occurs in this constructor:
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>     
>>>>>>> GeneticIndividu=
al::GeneticIndividual(shared_ptr<GeneticIndividual>
>>>>>>>> parent1,shared=
_ptr<GeneticIndividual> parent2,bool
>>>>>>> mate_multipoint_avg)
>>>>>>>> =

>>>>>>>> The following line occurs outside of the loop that goes through
>=
>> each
>>>>>>> link:
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>  bool chooseFirstParent =3D (rando=
mChoice<=3Dparent1->getFitness());
>>>>>>>>  
>>>>>>>> Then, inside the loo=
p for each link:
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>                     if (chooseFirstPare=
nt)
>>>>>>>>                     {
>>>>>>>>                         addLink=
(GeneticLinkGene(*link1));
>>>>>>>>                     }
>>>>>>>>         =
            else
>>>>>>>>                     {
>>>>>>>>                   =
      addLink(GeneticLinkGene(*link2));
>>>>>>>>                     }
>>>>=
>>>>  
>>>>>>>> So, it seems that *all* the links will be grabbed from one
=
>>> parent or
>>>>>>> the
>>>>>>>> other. Is that how it works in other ver=
sions of NEAT?
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>> Cheers,

> From: petar_chervenski <petar_chervenski@>
>>>>>>>>> Reply-To: "neat@yaho=
ogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>

>>>>>>> P=
NEAT?
>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>> Hi Jeff, 
>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>> Well I don't know=
 about the exact implementations of
> HyperNEAT you
>>>>>>> are
>>>>>>>>> u=
sing (note that P-NEAT is just NEAT with additive mutations
>>>>>>>>> disab=
led), but in principle crossover should choose genes
> randomly
>>>>>>>>> f=
rom both parents as it builds the offspring genome, the
> child. In
>>>>>>>=
>> HyperNEAT the crossover is different, there you actually do a
>>>>>>> re=
gular
>>>>>>>>> NEAT evolution of networks that build other networks based
=
> on the
>>>>>>>>> substrate configuration. That is, you only mate and muta=
te the
>>>>>>> CPPNs.
>>>>>>>>> But in the case you get lots of individuals=
 with equal
> fitness, I
>>>>>>>>> guess these individuals are clones. Perh=
aps the code frequently
>>>>>>>>> chooses the same individuals for mating? =
You can try to
> avoid this
>>>>>>> by
>>>>>>>>> introducing a loop in whic=
h you try candidates for a
> "father" that
>>>>>>> are
>>>>>>>>> not compat=
ible with the mother, that is, when their
> compatibility
>>>>>>>>> distanc=
e is 0.00, try again. There is another possibility,
> simply
>>>>>>>>> ever=
y mutation disturbs the CPPN and therefore the produced
>>>>>>> network is
=
>>>>>>>>> changed in such a magnitude that is has no chance for
> survival =
and
>>>>>>> is
>>>>>>>>> discarded. Even though there is speciation.
>>>>>>=
>>> 
>>>>>>>>> Peter
>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>> --- In neat@yahoogroup=
s.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> Hello all-
>>>>>>=
>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> Does crossover do anything in PNEAT and HyperNEAT?
>>>>>>>=
>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> PNEAT:
>>>>>>>>>> If I am reading the code correctly, durin=
g crossover, if the
>>>>>>>>> substrates are
>>>>>>>>>> the same (i.e. all =
links have the same ID), which is always the
>>>>>>> case
>>>>>>>>> in
>>>>=
>>>>>> P-NEAT, *all* of the link values are taken from either
> parent1 or
=
>>>>>>>>> parent2.
>>>>>>>>>> Isn't it more normal when crossing over to ta=
ke some from
> parent1
>>>>>>>>> and some
>>>>>>>>>> from parent2? Why grab=
 all from just one?
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> This means that in PNEAT crossov=
er does nothing, right? It will
>>>>>>>>> always grab
>>>>>>>>>> the substr=
ate of parent1 or the substrate of parent2.  If I
> track
>>>>>>>>> parent =
and
>>>>>>>>>> offspring fitness, 100% of the time the child has the exact
=
> same
>>>>>>>>> fitness as
>>>>>>>>>> one of the two parents.
>>>>>>>>>> 
=
>>>>>>>>>> On to HyperNEAT:
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> I tracked the fitness of=
 each parent and the resulting
> offspring.
>>>>>>>>> The odd
>>>>>>>>>> th=
ing is that the organisms that are crossed only (i.e.
> they are
>>>>>>>>> =
never
>>>>>>>>>> mutated) have the *exact* same fitness of one of their par=
ents
>>>>>>>>> 98.88% of the
>>>>>>>>>> time. In 20 runs, that was only 136=
 orgs out of 12257 that were
>>>>>>>>> crossed over
>>>>>>>>>> and not muta=
ted. That seems wrong, doesn't it? Why would these
>>>>>>> new
>>>>>>>>> li=
nks
>>>>>>>>>> have such a small impact? It turns out that this is because
=
>>>>>>> nearly
>>>>>>>>> every
>>>>>>>>>> time that there is an extra link =
that gets placed in the child,
>>>>>>> the
>>>>>>>>> parent
>>>>>>>>>> that=
 donated that link is also the parent whose weights are
> being
>>>>>>>>> g=
rabbed,
>>>>>>>>>> meaning that the crossover is only copying the parent
> =
(hence the
>>>>>>>>> same
>>>>>>>>>> fitness). It seems to me that crossove=
r should be much more
>>>>>>>>> disruptive, no?
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>=
>>>>>>> As a final test, I did a set of hyperneat and pneat runs
> with the=

>>>>>>>>> default
>>>>>>>>>> 'MutateOnlyProbability' parameter set to .25,=
 so 25% of orgs
>>>>>>> never
>>>>>>>>> are
>>>>>>>>>> candidates for cross=
over. I then ran experimental treatments
>>>>>>>>>> hyperneat-noCross and p=
neat-noCross where the
>>>>>>> MutateOnlyProbability
>>>>>>>>>> parameter w=
as set to 1, so no orgs were crossed over.
> Despite my
>>>>>>>>> comments
=
>>>>>>>>>> above, Hyperneat (with cross) did beat HyperNEAT-noCross,
> howe=
ver
>>>>>>>>> the
>>>>>>>>>> difference was not tremendous (although it doe=
s seem to be
>>>>>>>>> statistically
>>>>>>>>>> significant). For p-neat, t=
he reverse was true. Nevertheless,
>>>>>>> this
>>>>>>>>> is not a
>>>>>>>>=
>> perfect test of whether crossover pays dividends, because if
>>>>>>>>> c=
rossover does
>>>>>>>>>> nothing most of the time, and I increase MutateOnl=
yProbability
>>>>>>> from
>>>>>>>>> .25 to
>>>>>>>>>> 1, I have effectively=
 raised the mutation rate (only 80% of
>>>>>>> crossed
>>>>>>>>> orgs are
>=
>>>>>>>>> also mutated).
>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>> Are these the intended cons=
equences of crossover, or am I
> missing
>>>>>>>>> something?
>>>>>>>>>> 
>=
>>>>>>>>> Cheers,
>>>>>>>>>> Jeff Clune

ution Lab, Michigan State University
